bestBHT.bht: A powerful spirit overtakes the afflicted boy, bringing upon him sudden, violent convulsions. As the spirit tears at the boy, he is left foaming at the mouth, overwhelmed by its force. A medical description is used to convey the severity of this possession, employing terms often used to describe intense and sudden attacks of disease. The malevolent nature of the spirit is evident in its reluctance to depart, displaying a deliberate cruelty and malice.

Marvin Vincent: Used only once outside of the writings of Luke.
Frequent in medical writers, of sudden attacks of disease.
Archibald T. Robertson: It tears him with (accompanied with, μετα) foam.
The use of μετα αφρου is a medical item.
Common verb for rubbing together, crushing together like chains.
John Gill: And, lo, a spirit taketh him... and he suddenly crieth out; in a most terrible manner, giving dreadful shrieks.
it teareth him, that he foameth again; throws him into convulsions, so that he foams at the mouth.
hardly departeth from him; is very loath to leave him, even after he has distressed, convulsed, and bruised him in this dreadful manner, such was his cruelty and malice.

bhtAttempts.bht: A spirit seizes the boy in Luke 9:39, attacking him suddenly with convulsions that tear him apart, resulting in the boy foaming at the mouth. This disturbing scene is described in medical terms, emphasizing the severity and intensity of the possession. The spirit's cruel nature is further highlighted by the fact that it is reluctant to leave the boy even after causing such distress.

A powerful spirit overtakes the afflicted boy, bringing upon him sudden, violent convulsions. As the spirit tears at the boy, he is left foaming at the mouth, overwhelmed by its force. A medical description is used to convey the severity of this possession, employing terms often used to describe intense and sudden attacks of disease. The malevolent nature of the spirit is evident in its reluctance to depart, displaying a deliberate cruelty and malice.

A spirit takes hold of the boy, accompanied by sudden, violent convulsions that tear at his body. The intensity of the possession is described in medical terms, as if the boy is being crushed or chained together. As a result, the boy foams at the mouth, a visible manifestation of the distress caused by the spirit. Despite the anguish inflicted, the spirit lingers, reluctant to release its hold on the boy, demonstrating its cruel and malicious nature.

Seized by a spirit, the boy is subjected to abrupt and forceful convulsions that tear him apart, leaving him in a state of foaming. The usage of medical terms emphasizes the suddenness and intensity of the attack, drawing a parallel between this spiritual affliction and physical disease. The presence of the spirit persists, as it seems unwilling to depart, showcasing its malicious intent and unwavering cruelty towards the troubled boy.

A spirit takes hold of the boy, causing sudden and severe convulsions that tear at his body, resulting in a foaming reaction. The descriptive language used here, drawn from medical writings, conveys the intensity of the possession, likening it to a crushing and rubbing together of chains. Despite the distress it causes, the spirit appears reluctant to leave, displaying its malicious nature and unwillingness to let go of its hold on the boy.
